thread.title: County council spends £20m buying business rentals as it looks to save £50m

author: Amy Orton
title: County council spends £20m buying business rentals as it looks to save £50m
text:
County council spends £20m buying business rentals as it looks to save £50m Investments 'will give authority a regular income' Share Amy Orton Local Democracy Reporter 14:04, 22 MAY 2018 Leicestershire County Council has spent £20m on business rentals (Image: Getty images) Share Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! More than £20 million has been spent by Leicestershire County Council buying office buildings to rent out, as it faces making £50 million worth of cuts.
Embankment House in Nottingham and adjourning development land cost the council £12.6 million, and three office buildings on a business park in Lichfield set it back £11.4 million, according to a cabinet report.
The buildings were purchased using cash from the council's asset investment fund.
Councillor Byron Rhodes , deputy leader and finance spokesman for the council, said the properties should earn the council £5 million a year. Read More Frustration as 'inadequate' school loses head and deputy
But an opposition councillor has criticised the purchases, saying cash should have been spent on maintaining struggling services instead.
Councillor Terri Eynon, leader of the Labour Group, told the Leicester Mercury: “If we’ve got finance, why are we financing buildings when we could be supporting services?
“One of the biggest costs social care providers face is buildings. Why don’t we buy buildings for the care to be provided in? I've raised this in leaders’ meetings and my understanding is that this an entirely plausible idea.
“I understand that we need to invest but why does it always have to just be about finance?” Read More
In response, Coun Rhodes said: “If you invest in services the money is spent, what do you have then?
“Investing in these properties, and others, gives the council a regular income.
“In my view we should solve today’s problems today and with the money we have, and then invest some for the future.
“We try and reach a good balance. Read More Rise in number of children in care costs county an extra £2.4m
“The council currently has £265 million in outstanding debt, a few years ago we had £375 million.
“Most of our short term debt has now been paid off meaning the next payment on our debt is in 20 years time.
“Investing in these properties means we will be able to build up cash to make those payments when the time comes.”
Councillor Rhodes added that Embankment House, and an adjoining 5.3 acres of development land, was purchased from a foreign investor who was selling up due to its views on Brexit, meaning the council paid a ‘good price’.
One of the building’s tenants is the The Secretary of State For Communities and Local Government, something Coun Rhodes says the council considered as a benefit before they made a purchase.
He said: “These are two prime properties with reliable tenants and guaranteed income.” Like us on Facebook
